instructions.text: In each of Questions 1 to 50, choose the option that best answers the question or completes the statement.

Diagram of a plant root/stem region used in Questions 12 and 13, with arrows I–IV showing movement of water and solutes in xylem and phloem and the gases involved in photosynthesis.

questions.question: Which Biology Question Paper Type is given to you?
questions.explanation: The header of the paper states clearly that this is **Paper Type C**.

questions.question: Which of the following characterizes a mature plant cell?

options.text: the cytoplasm fills up the entire cell space
the nucleus is pushed to the centre of the cell
the cell wall is made up of cellulose
the nucleus is small and irregular in shape

questions.explanation: A distinctive feature of mature plant cells is a **cell wall composed mainly of cellulose** and a large central vacuole that pushes the cytoplasm to the periphery, not filling the entire space.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a function of the nucleus of a cell?

options.text: it controls the life processes of the cell
it translates genetic information for the manufacture of proteins
it stores and carries hereditary information
it is a reservoir of energy for the cell

questions.explanation: Energy reserves are mainly stored in **mitochondria and food vacuoles**, not in the nucleus. The nucleus controls cell activities, stores DNA and participates in protein synthesis.

questions.question: The dominant phase in the life cycle of a fern is the
questions.explanation: In ferns, the large leafy plant is the **diploid sporophyte**, which is the dominant phase. The gametophyte (prothallus) is small and short‑lived.

questions.question: Parental care is exhibited by
questions.explanation: Many **birds** incubate their eggs and feed and protect their young, showing clear parental care.

questions.explanation: The exact identities of animals I–IV are required to rank them correctly; these cannot be resolved clearly from the low‑resolution image, so the official order cannot be stated with confidence.

questions.question: Which of the animals represents the oldest creatures in terms of evolutionary history?
questions.explanation: Again, the precise animals labelled I–IV must be known to decide which lineage arose first; this is not readable from the screenshot.

questions.question: Which of the following groups of cells is devoid of true nuclei?
questions.explanation: Members of **kingdom Monera** (bacteria, blue‑green algae) are prokaryotes and lack a membrane‑bound (true) nucleus.

questions.instruction: Use the diagram of the bird (figure Bio2010_Bird).
questions.question: The main function of the feathers covering the part labelled I is to

options.text: prevent ectoparasites from attacking the animal
generate heat to keep the animal warm
serve as insulator to maintain body heat

questions.explanation: Contour feathers over the body help in **insulation**, conserving body heat.

questions.instruction: Use the diagram of the bird (figure Bio2010_Bird).
questions.question: Based on the shape and structure of the beak and feet, the bird represented is likely to feed mainly on
questions.explanation: Correct identification depends on the detailed form of the beak and feet in the original diagram; these are not distinguishable in the provided image.

questions.question: Which of the following is true of the transverse section of a dicot stem?

options.text: the epidermis is completely encircled by the cortex
the xylem is more interiorly located than the phloem
the cambium lies between the cortex and the vascular bundles
the vascular bundles are randomly scattered within the cortex

questions.explanation: In a dicot stem, vascular bundles are arranged in a ring with **xylem inside and phloem outside** separated by cambium.

questions.question: The movement of materials in the xylem and phloem tissues of the plant are represented by the arrows labelled
questions.explanation: The exact arrow positions corresponding to xylem and phloem movement are not readable with certainty from the screenshot, so the official combination cannot be given confidently.

questions.question: During photosynthesis, the arrow labelled II represents the

options.text: absorption of energy from the sun
release of oxygen as a by‑product

questions.explanation: Without clearly seeing where arrow II points (into or out of the leaf/plant), it is not possible to assign the correct gas movement.

questions.question: Which of the following is lacking in the diet of a person with kwashiorkor?
questions.explanation: Kwashiorkor is a **protein‑deficiency disease**, often in children after weaning.

questions.question: The mode of nutrition of sundew and bladderwort can be described as
questions.explanation: Sundew and bladderwort are insectivorous plants; they photosynthesize (autotrophic) but also digest insects (holozoic). Different texts emphasise different aspects; without the official key the intended option cannot be guaranteed.

questions.question: When the mixture of a food substance and Benedict’s solution was warmed, the solution changed from blue to brick‑red. This indicates the presence of
questions.explanation: A **brick‑red precipitate with Benedict’s reagent** is a positive test for reducing sugars (e.g. glucose).

questions.question: The primary structure responsible for pumping blood for circulation through the mammalian circulatory system is the
questions.explanation: The **left ventricle** has the thickest walls and pumps oxygenated blood to the entire body.

questions.question: Circulation of blood to all parts of the body except the lungs is through
questions.explanation: **Systemic circulation** distributes blood from the heart to the body tissues and back, excluding the lungs.

questions.question: Yeast respires anaerobically to convert simple sugar to carbon (IV) oxide and
questions.explanation: Anaerobic respiration (fermentation) in yeast produces **ethanol and CO₂**.

questions.question: The sheet of muscle that separates the thoracic and the abdominal cavities is the
questions.explanation: The **diaphragm** forms the muscular floor of the thoracic cavity, separating it from the abdomen.

questions.question: The oily substance that lubricates the mammalian hair to keep it flexible and water‑repellent is secreted by the
questions.explanation: **Sebaceous glands** secrete sebum, an oily substance that lubricates hair and skin.

questions.question: The outer layer of the kidney where the Bowman’s capsules are found is the
questions.explanation: Bowman’s capsules lie in the **renal cortex**.

questions.question: Which of the following stimuli is likely to elicit a nastic response in an organism?
questions.explanation: The folding of **Mimosa** leaves in response to touch is a classic **nastic movement**.

questions.question: In the male reproductive system of a mammal, sperm is stored in the
questions.explanation: Sperm mature and are stored in the **epididymis**.

questions.question: Chemosynthetic organisms are capable of manufacturing their food from simple inorganic substances through the process of
questions.explanation: Chemosynthetic bacteria obtain energy by **oxidizing** inorganic substances (e.g. ammonia, sulphur).

questions.question: The part of the human gut that has an acidic content is the
questions.explanation: The **stomach** secretes hydrochloric acid, giving its contents a low pH.

questions.question:
I. Stomata → Spirogyra
II. Alveoli → Earthworm
III. Malpighian tubule → Mammal
IV. Contractile vacuole → Protozoa.
Which of the above structures is correctly matched with the organism in which it is found?
questions.explanation: A **contractile vacuole** is typical of freshwater protozoa; the other pairings are incorrect (e.g. Malpighian tubules occur in insects, not mammals).

questions.question: A food chain always begins with a
questions.explanation: Producers (green plants, some algae) **fix energy** and form the first trophic level.

questions.question: Mycorrhizae promote plant growth by

options.text: absorbing inorganic ions from the soil
helping it to utilize atmospheric nitrogen

questions.explanation: Fungal hyphae of mycorrhizae greatly increase the root surface area for **mineral ion absorption**.

questions.question: The barrier between maternal and foetal blood is the
questions.explanation: The **placenta** allows exchange of materials between maternal and foetal blood without direct mixing.

questions.question: The blood component that has the greatest affinity for oxygen is the
questions.explanation: Red blood cells (**erythrocytes**) contain haemoglobin which binds oxygen.

questions.question: Which of the following organisms is mainly found in the marine habitat?
questions.explanation: **Dogfish** is a marine shark; the others are terrestrial or freshwater.

questions.question: The two halves of the pelvic girdle are joined together at the
questions.explanation: Left and right pelvic bones meet at the **pubic symphysis**.

questions.question:
I. Adoption of appropriate nocturnal habits
II. Burrowing
III. Adjusting their internal body temperature
IV. Possession of many sweat pores.
Which of the above are ways in which desert animals adapt to extreme heat of the environment?
questions.explanation: Desert animals avoid heat by being **nocturnal (I)**, **burrowing (II)** and regulating body temperature (III). Having many sweat pores (IV) would increase water loss, so it is not usually adaptive.

questions.question: Low annual rainfall, sparse vegetation, high diurnal temperatures and cold nights are characteristic features of the
questions.explanation: These are typical **desert** conditions.

questions.question: The activity of an organism which affects the survival of another organism in the same habitat constitutes
questions.explanation: Such interactions are **biotic factors** (e.g. predation, competition).

questions.question: The average number of individuals of a species per unit area of the habitat is the
questions.explanation: **Population density = number of individuals / unit area.**

questions.question: The vector for yellow fever is the
questions.explanation: **Aedes aegypti** transmits yellow fever.

questions.question: The loss of soil through erosion can be reduced by
questions.explanation: Practices like **crop rotation** and cover cropping help maintain vegetation cover, reducing erosion better than just watering or irrigation.

questions.question: The protozoan Plasmodium falciparum is transmitted by
questions.explanation: Human malaria parasites including **P. falciparum** are transmitted by **female Anopheles** mosquitoes.

questions.question: A dilute solution of phenylthiocarbamide tastes bitter to some people and is tasteless to others. This is an example of
questions.explanation: The ability to taste PTC is an **either‑or genetic trait**, showing discontinuous variation.

questions.question: In which plantation are all the trees between the height of 2–4 m?
questions.explanation: The exact ranges of each plantation’s curve cannot be read clearly from the small image; therefore the correct plantation cannot be identified with certainty.

questions.instruction: Use the tree‑height distribution graph (figure Bio2010_TreeHeight_Distribution).
questions.question: Which of the following is a true feature of plantation II?

options.text: it has the highest number of trees of about 2 m high
it has the highest number of trees
it has the highest number of tall trees
the height of all its trees range between 2 m and 6 m

questions.explanation: Again, the detailed distribution of heights for plantation II relative to the others cannot be resolved from the low‑resolution graph.

questions.question: Thyroxine and adrenalin are examples of hormones which control
questions.explanation: Thyroxine and adrenalin influence **metabolism and 'fight‑or‑flight' responses**, affecting behaviour.

questions.question: A pair of genes that control a trait is referred to as
questions.explanation: Each **allele** is one of a pair (or series) of genes that control a particular trait.

questions.question: The chromosome number of a cell before and after the process of meiosis is conventionally represented as
questions.explanation: Meiosis halves the chromosome number from **diploid (2n) to haploid (n)**.

questions.question: If both parents are heterozygous for a trait, the probability that an offspring will be recessive for that trait is
questions.explanation: A cross between **Aa × Aa** gives genotype ratio 1 AA : 2 Aa : 1 aa; the chance of recessive (aa) is **1/4**.

questions.question: At what stage in the life history of a mammal is the sex of an individual set?
questions.explanation: Sex is determined at **fertilization**, when either an X or Y sperm fertilizes the ovum.

questions.question: The main distinguishing features between the soldier termite and other members of the caste are the

options.text: presence of wings, possession of a small head and large thorax
presence of wings, possession of a large thorax and a small head
absence of wings, possession of strong mandibles and a large head
absence of wings, possession of big head and the absence of mandible

questions.explanation: Soldier termites are wingless with **large heads and powerful mandibles** for defence.

questions.question: The flippers of a whale and the fins of a fish are examples of
questions.explanation: Whales (mammals) and fishes evolved **similar structures (flippers/fins) independently** to adapt to aquatic life – an example of convergent evolution.
